block.p: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about violence in Iraq misidentified the Shiite Muslim holy day that millions of pilgrims began celebrating in the holy cities of Najaf and Karbala, raising a security concern that caused the assigning of extra American troops to those cities. The observance is Arbaniya, which commemorates the end of the mourning period for Imam Hussein, grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, who was killed by an overwhelming force of rival Sunni Muslims near Karbala in A.D. 680. (Ashura, when Shiites re-enact Hussein's death, falls 40 days earlier.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about violence in Iraq misidentified the Shiite Muslim holy day that millions of pilgrims began celebrating in the holy cities of Najaf and Karbala, raising a security concern that caused the assigning of extra American troops to those cities. The observance is Arbaniya, which commemorates the end of the mourning period for Imam Hussein, grandson of the Prophet Muhammad, who was killed by an overwhelming force of rival Sunni Muslims near Karbala in A.D. 680. (Ashura, when Shiites re-enact Hussein's death, falls 40 days earlier.)
